texts.definition: The feeling of caring about the outcome of actions or events in a game without having full control over them.
markups: <style="Definition">The feeling of caring about the outcome of actions or events in a game without having full control over them.</style>

Games may make players feel stress or apprehension, but this is typically less or a problem or even a wanted characteristic in them since players typically have willingly volunteered to take part of the gaming activity offered by the game. This <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> occurs when players have emotional investments in uncertain outcomes where some of the outcomes are perceived as being negative and others as being positive.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Risking to lose what one has invested in a game can easily create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. This may simply be time invested in completing a game such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Boulder%20Dash%20series">Boulder Dash</link></style> or reaching a high-score in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style>. However it can also be based on risking to lose real world objects or money, which can happen in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Marble%20Games">Marble Games</link></style>, some variants of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20the%20Gathering">Magic: the Gathering</link></style>, and most variants of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style> including <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Texas%20Hold'em">Texas Hold'em</link></style>. The presence of enemies that try to harm you is used in games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> can easily create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in games, and is often augmented through these games having dark and claustrophobic environments.

Having to complete tasks under time is another way games often create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sega%20Rally">Sega Rally</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Out%20Run">Out Run</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style> all do this, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Forbidden%20Island">Forbidden Island</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pandemic">Pandemic</link></style> shows examples of how this does actually not need to be linked to measuring actual progress of time.

<style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can also exist in games due to the need of trusting other players when one knows that this may not be a safe thing to do. Examples of games with this type of <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diplomacy">Diplomacy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illuminati">Illuminati</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Intrigue">Intrigue</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Junta">Junta</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/So%20Long%20Sucker">So Long Sucker</link></style>.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

Making players feel <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> depends on making them care about some part of the game and then introducing <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-outcome">Uncertainty of Outcome</link></style>. Overarching goals that players can care about is of course winning the game, and both <style="Link"><link="winning-ending-gameplay">Winning by Ending Gameplay</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="winner-gameplay-ends">Winner determined after Gameplay Ends</link></style> provides ways of doing this with more specific gameplay characteristics. <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> are typical ways of achieving <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> through an <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-outcome">Uncertainty of Outcome</link></style>, but this can be strengthened through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> choices, the possibility to feel <style="Link"><link="luck">Luck</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="end-state-scoring">End State Scoring</link></style> typically also does this through either the game state being complex enough that an accurate calculation is difficult or impossible to do, or through being the phase in which the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> is revealed. <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style> can cause <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> both in that the outcome can be uncertain and that one has to perform, possibly in front of others. <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style> can amplify this, and even make gameplay actions which require no performative aspects to cause <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> because others may see one lose or win.

<style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="early-elimination">Early Elimination</link></style> are generic patterns to increase <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> to players by threatening to remove them from the ongoing game instance. <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> is typically a part of these patterns but can be used independently of these to raise <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in games. <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style>, and especially <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Rewards">Extra-Game Rewards</link></style>, can be used to increase any <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> present from gameplay in a game, but may also provide <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> by itself. <style="Link"><link="sanctioned-cheating">Sanctioned Cheating</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> is related to this type of <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in that knowing that it exists make players have to consider what can be seen in one sense as <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style> from other players. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> is a way to modulate <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>, the more <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> players feel, the more <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> they will also likely feel as long as they started with some <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. One way of creating this <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> is to give players a <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style>.

One of the primary ways to make it doubtful that things will turn in the best possible way for players is to introduce opposition. The two primary categories for this is <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style>. The former is typically done through <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> controlled by <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> while the latter is done through players and other <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>. To be in opposition, <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style> need to be set up, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competitions">Competition</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflict</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> goals (for opposition based on <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style> with no positive effects that automatically consume players' <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> provide similar <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> to players as <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> and opposing players). The most common types of specific <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style> are probably <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style> but <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> provides another example that does not require <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>. While losing a game or a local competition can be the sole effect of being outdone by one's opposition, the threat of suffering <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style>, during gameplay can further increase <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. A variety of this, that cannot be used too often, is to expose players to <style="Link"><link="fake-game-overs">Fake Game Overs</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> based on opposition can be modulated so that it is maintained for longer periods of gameplay time through <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>. This can be further modulated by using <style="Link"><link="near-miss-indicators">Near Miss Indicators</link></style>, forcing players to make decisions related to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paper-Rock-Scissors">Paper-Rock-Scissors</link></style> structures of attacking, by making the <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> more powerful over time through <style="Link"><link="ever-increasing-difficulty">Ever Increasing Difficulty</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> being a typical example), or by making <style="Link"><link="tied-results">Tied Results</link></style> impossible through <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can be increased by making gameplay actions more difficult for players. <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> is an obvious solution while <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> can be used to try and make all players have <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> by making it hard for leading players to maintain their position. One of the ways games can be more difficult is to stress players to perform actions more quickly. <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>, e.g. how long <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> last or how long one has to do <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, does this by forcing players to have to try to complete their actions in less time than they may want to use. The <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> this produces can in turn by modified by <style="Link"><link="sustenance-rewards">Sustenance Rewards</link></style> that both relieves it to a degree and prolongs it. While <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> do not in themselves create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>, the need of doing either <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> or feeling the need for <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> in such games can be enough to create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in a game. <style="Link"><link="quick-time-events">Quick Time Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="speedruns">Speedruns</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="temporary-abilities">Temporary Abilities</link></style> are other examples of patterns that can force players to have to act faster than they prefer. <style="Link"><link="shrinking-game-worlds">Shrinking Game Worlds</link></style> can combine the need to perform actions quickly with also limiting the gameplay areas in which these can be done (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Forbidden%20Island">Forbidden Island</link></style> shows how this can provide <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in a <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based</link></style> co-operative game). A final example of how gameplay actions can be made more difficult is to deny players any periods when they relax by using <style="Link"><link="always-vulnerable">Always Vulnerable</link></style>.

Most games provide players with some game elements which are designated as theirs or whom they represent in the game. Such <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> provide a natural starting point for players to be concerned about as do <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="territories">Territories</link></style> which players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> over but which can be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stolen</link></style> can also do this. While all these may give players initial parts of the game to care about, this caring can be increase during gameplay if the players' <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> are tied to them, e.g. through <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style>.

Another way of increasing <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> is removing agency for players when they have started actions. <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> is an old solution to this found in classical board games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> since once one has completed ones turn one cannot affect the game until the other player has done his or her turn, and one will have to accept mistakes one has made. <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style>, either involuntary or through committing to <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style>, is another way to make players temporary unable to do anything about their game situation. <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style> does not necessary remove overall agency but can make players have to wait for wanted effects in a game without being able to quicken their arrival when can also cause <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style> also does this but adds the factor that some other players or <style="Link"><link="agents">Agent</link></style> can decide the outcome; in general any possibility of <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traitors">Traitors</link></style> creates <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in a game. Examples of games where this is especially obvious is <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diplomacy">Diplomacy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/So%20Long%20Sucker">So Long Sucker</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Intrigue">Intrigue</link></style>. Removing players from games can be seen as the ultimate form of removing player agency, so having <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> is a way to add <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> to games. This can be even greater if <style="Link"><link="early-elimination">Early Elimination</link></style> is possible, but this can also backfire since players may not be committed enough to the gameplay when the elimination occurs unless some type of commitment is enforced at the beginning of the game, e.g. through <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style>.

Limiting how long players have to try and succeed with actions is an effective way to create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. This can be done as explicit <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> or be achieved implicitly through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Show%20Must%20Go%20On">The Show Must Go On</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="time-pressure">Time Pressure</link></style> increases <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> but does not have to provide explicit <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> to do so, as for example having to be the first to complete a task shows. <style="Link"><link="attention-demanding-gameplay">Attention Demanding Gameplay</link></style> creates <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> by requiring players to focus on the gameplay at all time to avoid <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>. Both these types of <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can then be further increased by requiring <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style> or having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style>. Another way to modulate the <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> is by restricting players' powers or freedom, for example, by <style="Link"><link="shrinking-game-worlds">Shrinking Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style>. The two latter work more efficiently if players have either had greater freedom earlier or if they have lesser freedom or power compared to others.

Forcing players to make commitments and then not letting them affect the outcome, or at least limit how they can affect the outcome, can create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> can do this and are similar in this since they are activities that require <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style>, and both are usually combined with other patterns that can create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in this fashion, for example <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="token-placement">Token Placement</link></style> are three other activities that can provide <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in themselves and can be used together with the just mentioned patterns to provide even more <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. Both <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="camping">Camping</link></style> can cause <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in relation to locations of a game, but while in the former case this is due to the risk of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> being prepared to attack as soon as one spawns in the latter case this has more to do with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> and having to trust that one has chosen a good place to camp. <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style> combined with <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="positive-feedback-loops">Positive Feedback Loops</link></style> can also create this form of <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> as the invested <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> are bound, and failed investments cause not only the already invested resources to be lost but lessen the value of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> that have not yet been invested. This form of <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can be further modulated through the presence of <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style> but can be ruined by <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Perfect%20Information">Perfect Information</link></style> about the evaluation function and all the game state values that affect the function. <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can however be lost instead of created if the players lose a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Perceived%20Chance%20to%20Succeed">Perceived Chance to Succeed</link></style> because of necessary <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style>, extended <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>. Even if they hinder players from performing actions, <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style> in general have a negative effect on <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> since nothing negative can happen to players' effort while a game is being paused. <style="Link"><link="feigned-die-rolls">Feigned Die Rolls</link></style> is a specific technique <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can use to increase <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> of players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style>, both by introducing <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style> and by allows them to develop <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> according to what creates <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> best rather than submitting to random developments.

<style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can be caused by putting players in the position of missing <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> or in the position of receiving <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, which either affect themselves or something with which they have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style>. While how much <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> specific <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> can give depend on individual players and the specific game context, a relative order among categories can be made where <style="Link"><link="energy-penalties">Energy Penalties</link></style> give less <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> than <style="Link"><link="life-penalties">Life Penalties</link></style> which in turn give less <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> than <style="Link"><link="game-termination-penalties">Game Termination Penalties</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="setback-penalties">Setback Penalties</link></style> as a category provides less <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> than all these types of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style> categories. Especially <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competitions">Competitions</link></style> and questions of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> can evoke <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>, in the latter case either because players have <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals or because opponents want to take away <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> of something from players. Having <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> which players use to compete against each other easily captures these aspects of <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> (and is a type of <style="Link"><link="races">Race</link></style>). Adding <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can be achieved when using <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> by having <style="Link"><link="secret-scoring-mechanisms">Secret Scoring Mechanisms</link></style>; more generally <style="Link"><link="secret-goals">Secret Goals</link></style> can add <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> because not only do players need to compete against each other, they need to also try to figure out what goals the other players actually have.

Many of the patterns in the previous two sections are related to <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>, something that can cause <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in itself as long as it can be lost in some way. <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style> can cause <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in relation to <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> as well, here by pointing out how much a player stands to lose or how little remains before the <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> pays off. Games that make use of <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style> can also cause <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in this way where the gameplay effort made by players can be seen as <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>.

Many aspects of <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> where players have to rely on other players' actions give rise to <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. Any interaction where <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style> or possibility for disinformation exists due to player communication can generate <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> (e.g. due to the use of <style="Link"><link="alternate-reality-gameplay">Alternate Reality Gameplay</link></style>), but it is especially likely to occur with <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style> or when <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style> is possible. Examples when <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can be created in this fashion include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Decided%20Distributions">Player-Decided Distributions</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> and the presence of <style="Link"><link="shared-resources">Shared Resources</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> related to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> exists in many cases for both the ones that can lose from the actions and the ones that can gain, as is typical in <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style>. In general, any gameplay which depend on <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style> can provide <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> further simply because of this requirement. In addition, any type of gameplay which requires communication can become tenser if it needs to be done with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Communication%20Abilities">Limited Communication Abilities</link></style> or where <style="Link"><link="ambiguous-responses">Ambiguous Responses</link></style> can occur. The risk of being the target of <style="Link"><link="guilting">Guilting</link></style> can create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in itself.

Many activities and goals in games combine several of the aspects discussed above. For example, <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> activities give players opponents and threaten to take cause <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> or take <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style> can combine the risk of losing ongoing <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> with the threats of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, e.g. through <style="Link"><link="king-hill">King of the Hill</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals.

<style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can be difficult to evoke in players when some other specific patterns are present. Games with <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="framed-freedom">Framed Freedom</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="pottering">Pottering</link></style> are specifically designed to avoid <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>, so these are naturally difficult to combine with the pattern. <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style> do this also, but at localized areas of the games (which may be irrelevant if these are the only places a player can act). <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> function similarly but relate to <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> can create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>, it can also lower or remove <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in players since they can plan without interruption when it is their turn, and often even when it is not. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Reversibility">Reversibility</link></style> and the possibility to recreate previous game states through <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style> lessens <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>, as players can replay moments that contained <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> and the feeling is less likely to be as strong on subsequent exposures. Related to this, repeated exposure to the same type of challenges can remove <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. This can partly be mitigated by <style="Link"><link="ever-increasing-difficulty">Ever Increasing Difficulty</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style>, as for example naturally occurs in <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style> or can be explicitly designed through <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

<style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> can create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in games in the same ways as in other narrative mediums, and examples of more specific narration-related patterns include <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style> can be especially suited for creating <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> since they limit players' knowledge about the diegesis which can cause <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in itself. <style="Link"><link="alternate-reality-gameplay">Alternate Reality Gameplay</link></style> causes <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> in a related way but here part of the <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> is that players do not know what is part of the game and what is not. While <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> can be most prepared to create <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>, they do suffer from not maintaining this if players play games containing these several times.

Many times, waiting for an activity to start can cause more <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> than the activity itself. <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> is a typical case of this, and knowing that <style="Link"><link="surprise-attacks">Surprise Attacks</link></style> may happen, or are likely to happen soon, may cause much more <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> than the actual <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> when it has started.

However, when <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> do not contain <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>, or when the unfolding of them causes players to have <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, players are likely to lose any feeling of <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style>. <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can however notice these occurrences and adjust accordingly to mitigate this problem.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> is one of the more direct ways games can be designed to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>. While this can be a negative to some players, it can instead provide <style="Link"><link="fubar-enjoyment">FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style> to others and succeeding with some activity while under <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> is likely to increase the perceived <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> of the activity. Even failing while playing under <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can be positive since players can after the fact have <style="Link"><link="spectacular-failure-enjoyment">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</link></style>. These experiences can however easily spill over from games into the real world as <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style>, and the risk for this happening increase if the consequences are in the form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Rewards">Extra-Game Rewards</link></style> or they are used in combination with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>.

Repeated exposure to the same form of events or actions decreases the <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> they cause, so <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> and <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> is difficult to combine, especially if the <style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> is caused by <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, or other effects that rely on players not knowing what will occur.

<style="CurrentLink">Tension</style> can make some activities more difficult to perform. One such activity is <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> and another one is <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>.
